intro: Tetratheca paynterae subsp. cremnobata, commonly known as the Kangaroo Island tetratheca, is a flowering plant native to South Australia. It is a shrub that typically grows in heathlands and open forests, thriving in well-drained soils. The plant produces small, white, five-petaled flowers that bloom in spring, attracting pollinators such as bees and birds. Its leaves are narrow and linear, with a distinctive greyish-green color and a hairy texture. This subspecies is notable for its ecological significance and is considered a rare and endangered species in its native habitat.
